overview_of_class: This course is a 2-level introduction to traditional Chinese history from the Neolithic to the beginning of the late imperial period (ca. 1600). It will address important topics in recorded Chinese history: the Neolithic and Bronze Age foundations of Chinese civilization; the question of how the geographical space we call China became "Chinese;" the evolution of classical Chinese philosophy; the splendor and social tensions of the commercialized urban centers; the increasing constriction of women's lives after the twelfth century; the Mongol conquest of Eurasia; the shift in Eurasian trade from caravan to maritime travel; and some of the continuities and transformations that mark early modern China. Particular attention will be paid to the Tang-Song Transition (or the medieval Chinese revolution) from the eighth to the thirteenth centuries, a period of fundamental commercial, religious, philosophical, and social transformation.
name: Chinese Civilization
subject: HISTORY
